Comment: The french queen dines on white horse, a delicacy in those parts.  Before moving the knight to the side of the board advancing the g pawn one square would have offered it some cover.  Otherwise, you're sacrificing a valuable piece just to draw the french (black) queen out.

Ouch!  White either protect the c2 pawn or risk losing a rook.  White COULD castle, and sacrifice the pawn for black's f6 pawn.

The trouble here is that white's rook remains at risk from the black knight.  There is still going to be material exchange.  My guess is black will take white's bishop.
The trouble here is that white's rook remains at risk from the black knight.  There is still going to be material exchange.  My guess is black will take white's bishop.

?  White's queen falls easy prey here.  QxQ+ forces black to do something so white can castle and protect the a1 rook from the continued black knight threat.  This pawn threat against the bishop does nothing to save the white queen.  The trade would have given white a big advantage, now that he was ahead 3 points.
